__data__.text:
Glenn Youngkin, a Republican, became Virginia's governor on January 15, 2022, along with historically diverse ticket mates. His inauguration happened during the COVID-19 pandemic and a winter storm. Youngkin participated in a community service project and held several inauguration events. His speech had a religious and confident tone, with a mix of bipartisanship and optimism, but he faced criticism for signing polarizing executive actions right after.

Youngkin's first day included signing 11 executive actions, such as banning "inherently divisive concepts" like critical race theory (CRT) from schools, even though it's not part of the curriculum. This move has been criticized as an attempt to "whitewash" history and "erase black history." Two actions rescinded previous COVID-19 regulations, like the statewide mask mandate for public schools and the vaccine mandate for state employees.

Reference(s):
- The Washington Post
- The Associated Press
- NPR
- The Richmond Times-Dispatch

Glenn Youngkin, Virginia's new governor, faced criticism for his stance on critical race theory (CRT) and his decision to ban "inherently divisive concepts" from schools, which some view as an attempt to "whitewash" history. His first day in office included signing executive actions that rescinded COVID-19 regulations, such as the statewide mask mandate for public schools and the vaccine mandate for state employees. These actions have been met with legal challenges, with lawsuits arguing that they infringe upon local control and violate state laws. A federal judge recently ruled that school districts in Virginia could choose to require masking in areas frequented by certain plaintiffs. Additionally, Youngkin's repeal of public school mask mandates has been criticized for introducing controversy and confusion.

After facing criticism for his stance on critical race theory and rolling back COVID-19 regulations, Governor Glenn Youngkin joined a lawsuit against the Loudoun County school system, challenging their mask mandate. School systems started dropping mask mandates following Youngkin's executive order. A federal judge's ruling allowed school districts to choose masking, but did not overturn the executive order. Youngkin announced his 16-member cabinet at a slower pace than previous governors, focusing on education by nominating Aimee Rogstad Guidera as Secretary of Education instead of Kirk Cox. His cabinet nominees include five women and three African Americans, many of whom are new to government and from the private sector, creating a learning curve for the new administration. Some nominees have prior experience in Virginia governorships or the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank. Richard Cullen, an experienced attorney, was chosen as counselor, a cabinet-level position.

Youngkin has named Daniel Gade as Commissioner of Virginia's Department of Veterans Services and Richard Cullen as counselor, a cabinet-level position. Cullen, a seasoned attorney and establishment figure, is seen as a nod to the traditional political order in Virginia. The Chief Diversity Officer position, established by Northam, has been filled by Angela Sailor, an executive at the Heritage Foundation. Youngkin issued an executive order changing the focus of the Office of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion to include unborn children, parental involvement, assisting people with disabilities, promoting viewpoint diversity, and creating equal opportunity. The initial nomination of Andrew Wheeler, a former EPA Administrator and coal lobbyist, as Secretary of Natural Resources was voted down by the Democratic-controlled State Senate. Wheeler later became a senior advisor and then head of the Office of Regulatory Management, both roles not requiring legislative approval. The vote on Wheeler's nomination led to Republicans retaliating against Democrats by blocking judicial appointments.

After Wheeler's nomination as Secretary of Natural Resources was rejected by the State Senate, he was appointed as a senior advisor and then head of the newly established Office of Regulatory Management, both roles not requiring legislative approval. This followed Republicans blocking judicial appointments and later rejecting some of Northam's nominees to state boards in retaliation for opposing Wheeler's nomination. The conflict escalated throughout the 2022 legislative session, with Youngkin issuing vetoes on Democratic-sponsored bills and using unpaid advisors, such as Matthew Moran and Aubrey Layne, who continued to receive payment from their respective employers. Youngkin has positioned himself as "pro-life" but supports legal access to abortion in cases of rape, incest, or protecting the mother's life.

Following the rejection of his nomination as Secretary of Natural Resources, Wheeler became a senior advisor and then head of the Office of Regulatory Management. The conflict over his nomination led to Republicans blocking judicial appointments and rejecting some of Northam's nominees, escalating throughout the 2022 legislative session. Youngkin, who describes himself as "pro-life" but supports legal access to abortion in certain cases, appointed Matthew Moran as a full-time senior political adviser and Aubrey Layne as an unpaid advisor, both while they maintained outside employment. Youngkin introduced a failed budget amendment to limit public funding of abortion services, and after the Dobbs v. Jackson draft opinion leak, he called for federal intervention against protests targeting conservative Supreme Court Justices' homes. In response to the final Dobbs opinion, Youngkin announced support for abortion access restrictions and tasked four Republican state lawmakers with developing related legislation, advocating for a 15-week ban but suggesting a 20-week ban as a possible compromise. Youngkin supports the COVID-19 vaccination effort but opposes mandates, and challenged the Biden administration's employer vaccine mandate.

Youngkin supports abortion restrictions, proposing a 15-week ban with exceptions for rape, incest, and mother's life, and is open to further limitations if votes allow. He advocates for the COVID-19 vaccination effort but opposes mandates, having challenged the Biden administration's employer vaccine mandate and opposing school mask mandates. He signed an executive order to repeal the statewide mask mandate, which was later overturned in part by a court ruling and a settlement with the ACLU. Youngkin also rescinded the vaccine mandate for state employees and revoked pandemic safety standards set by the previous administration. These actions were taken after Republicans, in response to Wheeler's nomination rejection, blocked judicial appointments and rejected some of Northam's nominees, escalating conflicts throughout the 2022 legislative session.

Youngkin's administration has taken several steps regarding COVID-19 safety measures and telework policies. They revoked Virginia's first-in-the-nation workplace safety standards, which included a mask mandate for high-risk indoor areas, after House Republicans rejected the nominations of two board members expected to vote against revoking the standards. The administration also ceased contact tracing efforts, shifted focus to high-risk settings, and asked individuals to personally notify contacts. In May 2022, Youngkin announced a new telework policy for executive branch employees, limiting telework to one day a week or with higher-level approvals for more days, with exemptions for certain agencies. This policy change led to hundreds of state employees resigning before its implementation in July.

In addition to these changes, Youngkin signed a bill in 2022 that reversed a 2021 amendment to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act. The new bill gives law enforcement discretion over releasing files related to closed investigations, but still requires access to be granted to victims' families and attorneys working on post-conviction proceedings. If law enforcement chooses to fulfill other requests, they must notify involved victims, who can then object and file for an injunction.

Youngkin's administration made changes to Virginia's FOIA law, giving law enforcement discretion over releasing files related to closed investigations while maintaining access for victims' families and attorneys. Victims can object and file for an injunction if other requests are fulfilled. He vetoed a bill that would have shifted authority for hiring a local auditor of police misconduct in Arlington County from the County Manager to the County Board. Youngkin also signed a bill exempting small localities from implementing the Marcus alert system, which involves mental health professionals in responding to mental health crises reported to 911. Additionally, he approved a bill prohibiting law enforcement agencies from using quotas for ticket-writing or arrests and limiting the expansion of an early release program for inmates earning time off sentences through good behavior.

Youngkin's administration modified Virginia's FOIA law, granting law enforcement discretion over releasing closed investigation files while preserving access for victims' families and attorneys. He also vetoed a bill that would have transferred the authority for hiring a local police misconduct auditor in Arlington County from the County Manager to the County Board. Furthermore, he approved a bill exempting small localities from implementing the Marcus alert system and prohibiting law enforcement agencies from using quotas for ticket-writing or arrests. Youngkin limited an early release program for inmates by introducing an amendment to the 2022 state budget, making inmates convicted of violent crimes ineligible for the expanded program.

During his campaign, Youngkin claimed Virginia's economy was struggling, despite low unemployment, a budget surplus, and a AAA bond rating. He initially proposed eliminating Virginia's individual income tax, but later retracted it, instead announcing a series of more modest tax cut proposals, including eliminating the grocery tax, suspending the gas tax increase, and offering tax rebates and deductions. These proposals would have amounted to $3.2 billion in tax cuts if enacted. Youngkin planned to fund the tax cuts with the state's budget surplus.

After announcing more modest tax cut proposals during his campaign, Youngkin, upon taking office, signed a state budget with $4 billion in tax cuts. The budget included an increase in the standard deduction for personal income tax, one-time tax rebates, and a partial elimination of Virginia's grocery tax. However, Democrats blocked Youngkin's proposal to eliminate a local grocery tax and his goal of offering gas tax relief. The budget also featured a military pension tax exemption and a refundable earned income tax credit, the latter being a longtime Democratic priority. Youngkin's campaign economic advisor, Stephen Moore, had previously helped oversee significant tax cuts in Kansas, which were criticized for leading to spending cuts in education and transportation. The budget's centerpiece was the increased standard deduction, while other aspects aligned with Northam's outgoing budget proposals.

Youngkin's budget included a longtime Democratic priority, an expanded standard deduction for low-income tax filers, despite previous Republican opposition. A proposed gas tax relief initiative by Youngkin was blocked by Democrats, who argued it would reduce transportation revenue and benefit the oil industry and out-of-state drivers. Youngkin also failed to pass a proposal for public referendums on local real estate tax increases and vetoed a bill enhancing judges' ability to mandate landlord code compliance.

Despite bipartisan support for the budget, some Democrats opposed the significant tax cuts, arguing that funds for affordable housing, mental health services, gun violence prevention, and transportation were insufficient. Youngkin has not announced plans for a grant to address inequities in the Virginia Employment Commission's operations and opposes further investments in affordable housing.

Education was a central theme in Youngkin's campaign, with a focus on cultural issues and curriculum. Despite Politifact's findings that critical race theory was not part of state curriculum standards, Youngkin campaigned against its supposed pervasive teaching. He has also expressed opposition to the gradual minimum wage increase, right-to-work law repeal, and collective bargaining rights for public employees.

Youngkin's education platform was a major focus of his campaign, with an emphasis on cultural issues and curriculum. He won the election partly due to the support of Loudoun County parents who opposed progressive school policies. Despite critical race theory not being part of the state curriculum, Youngkin campaigned against its supposed teaching. He also opposed transgender student protections, calling for the repeal of related policies and supporting teachers who refuse to use preferred pronouns. Upon taking office, he banned critical race theory in schools and diversity trainings, and canceled the Virginia Mathematics Pathways Initiative. His administration plans to repeal protections for transgender students. These actions were taken despite education officials denying claims about the elimination of advanced math classes or teaching critical race theory.

Youngkin, after taking office, took actions against the Virginia Math Pathways Initiative, which he and other conservatives claimed would "dumb down" standards and eliminate advanced high school math classes. However, education officials denied these claims and stated that the program aimed to prioritize data science and analytics while still offering calculus at an accelerated pace. No plans to eliminate advanced classes existed. Following this, Youngkin signed a bill allowing parents to review and opt their children out of material with "sexually explicit content," a first in the nation. He also advocated for a bill to reverse admissions process reforms aimed at increasing racial diversity in some Governor's Schools, but it failed in the State Senate. Youngkin established a tipline for reporting "divisive practices" in schools and urged colleges to consider political diversity in hiring. He enlisted a conservative think tank to revise Virginia's educational standards for history and social sciences.

After taking office, Youngkin established a tipline for reporting "divisive practices" in schools, which he characterized as a way for parents to report violations of their fundamental rights and inherently divisive practices. However, critics, including a teachers union, Democrats, and some parents, viewed it as divisive, authoritarian, and unfairly targeting educators. The tipline was compared to systems set up by previous governors for reporting business and health violations, but was widely criticized and mocked, with many, including educators and the media, predicting it would backfire. Despite multiple inquiries, the Youngkin administration did not disclose how complaints sent to the tipline would be used, and eventually closed it down in September 2022, citing a lack of tips. The administration also faced a lawsuit from over a dozen media outlets seeking access to the emails sent to the tipline. In addition, Youngkin attempted to amend a bill concerning elections for the Loudoun County School Board, aiming to hold the board accountable for their handling of sexual assault cases, but the amendment was unsuccessful.

After taking office, Youngkin established a tip line for reporting "divisive practices" in schools, but it was criticized as divisive and authoritarian. It was shut down in September 2022 due to lack of use, as per the Washington Post. In the 2022 legislative session, Youngkin attempted to amend a bill concerning elections for the Loudoun County School Board, aiming to hold the board accountable for their handling of sexual assault cases. However, this move was seen as an attempt to subvert the election results and was met with harsh partisan criticism. Youngkin also repealed protections for transgender students, replacing them with policies that require student-access to school facilities and programs to be determined by biological sex and mandate the use of legal documentation for name or gender changes. These actions have been criticized for potentially requiring teachers to out students to their parents and for possibly violating Virginia law. The Washington Post noted that Youngkin's actions fit into a national trend among Republicans of curtailing the rights of transgender Americans. Legal challenges to Youngkin's policies are expected.

After taking office, Youngkin implemented policies concerning transgender students that replace previous protections with requirements based on biological sex, leading to criticism and expected legal challenges. The policies may violate state law and the Virginia Human Rights Act, and were met with protests by thousands of students. In contrast, both Northam and Democratic nominee McAuliffe had proposed increasing education budgets with a focus on teacher salaries, STEM, ESL, and internet access, while Youngkin's platform lacked details and focused on cultural issues. However, Youngkin had the opportunity to sign a record-breaking education budget of $19.2 billion in 2022, surpassing Republican preferences, due to a state revenue surplus inherited from Northam. The budget included a 10% salary increase for teachers and $1.25 billion for school construction, but still falls short of fully addressing the state's aging school infrastructure needs.

Following his election, Youngkin's education policies focus on addressing teacher shortages and expanding charter and lab schools, despite initial plans to prioritize cultural issues. He issued an executive order to alleviate teacher shortages by simplifying licensure and providing funding for severe shortages. The budget he signed includes a 10% salary increase, $1,000 bonuses, and $1.25 billion for school construction, but falls short of fully addressing infrastructure needs. Youngkin supports expanding charter schools to match North Carolina's numbers and shifting approval authority to regional charter school divisions. He also aims to re-establish lab schools through partnerships with various institutions, allowing private businesses to participate, and changing public school funding for lab school students. An amendment to enact this funding change was not adopted. Critics argue that these changes may lower teaching standards and result from escalated education-related culture wars.

Post-election, Youngkin's education policies focus on addressing teacher shortages, expanding charter and lab schools, and enhancing school safety. He has taken steps to simplify teacher licensure, increase salaries, and construct schools. Youngkin advocates for private business partnerships in lab schools, which can be new or converted from existing schools, with a preference for historically black colleges and underserved communities. His plan to change public school funding to redirect per-pupil funding to lab schools was not adopted. Although his goal of re-establishing lab schools is supported, the funding change faces criticism. Youngkin signed legislation allowing college athletes to profit from their name, image, and likeness, and restored the requirement for principals to report certain misdemeanor crimes on school grounds. He also mandated digital floor plans for public schools and hazing prevention training for student organizations. Regarding climate change, Youngkin is unclear about its cause, supports adaptation efforts, and opposes the Clean Economy Act. He withdrew Virginia from the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, calling it a "carbon tax," despite potential revenue loss for flood control and energy assistance.

After the election, Youngkin prioritized nuclear energy, planning to build a small modular reactor in Southwest Virginia. He withdrew Virginia from the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, calling it a "carbon tax," despite potential revenue loss for flood control and energy assistance. He aimed to reevaluate the initiative due to potential legal limitations in withdrawing without legislative approval. Youngkin also attempted to block a law aligning Virginia's vehicle emissions standards with California's and opposed a flood preparedness bill.

In April 2022, Youngkin rescinded a ban on single-use plastics at executive branch state agencies and transferred permitting authority from citizen review boards to the Department of Environmental Quality. This change came after the Air Pollution Control Board, one of the affected boards, denied a permit for a compressor station of the Mountain Valley Pipeline, angering business groups.

In the 2022 legislative session, Youngkin vetoed bills that would have set a statute of limitations on medical debt collection and prohibited health insurance companies from charging higher premiums for tobacco use, both of which had broad bipartisan support. His veto of the latter bill contradicted national studies and a bipartisan study commission's recommendation.

Post-election, Youngkin prioritized nuclear energy and eased regulations on single-use plastics and permitting processes, favoring business groups over environmental and health care advocates. He vetoed bipartisan-backed bills, including a medical debt collection statute of limitations and a tobacco use premium ban, despite national studies indicating cost reduction. An amendment reallocated financial aid from undocumented immigrants to historically black colleges, drawing criticism for pitting disadvantaged groups against each other. Youngkin personally opposes same-sex marriage but maintains he won't interfere, though his actions have sparked controversy among LGBTQ+ groups. He also expressed reluctance regarding potential Supreme Court actions on same-sex marriage. Youngkin proposed re-criminalizing marijuana possession over two ounces, contrasting with the previous administration's decriminalization approach.

After his election, Youngkin prioritized nuclear energy and eased regulations on single-use plastics, favoring business groups. He vetoed several bipartisan-backed bills, including a same-sex marriage ban amendment reversal, due to potential Supreme Court actions. Regarding marijuana, Youngkin proposed re-criminalizing possession over two ounces, which was previously decriminalized, while implementing misdemeanor penalties for possessing over the legal amount.

Youngkin has continued restoring voting rights to former felons, but an amendment for automatic voting rights restoration was halted due to Republican opposition. He also campaigned for various Republican candidates in the 2022 federal midterms, including those who endorsed false claims about the 2020 election, drawing criticism from moderate Republicans.

In terms of marijuana policy, Youngkin's administration made possessing between four ounces and a pound of marijuana in public a Class 3 misdemeanor for a first-time offense and a Class 2 misdemeanor for repeat offenses. They also banned cannabis products shaped as animals, humans, vehicles, or fruits to prevent accidental consumption by children. Additionally, patients can now purchase medical marijuana immediately upon receiving a certificate from a registered medical provider, addressing long wait times during the registration process. Youngkin proposed raising the legal age for purchasing CBD products to 21 and banning products containing Delta-8 THC.

In response to the Washington Post's concerns about the potential Supreme Court reversal of the same-sex marriage ban amendment, Youngkin stated, "I can't live in the world of hypotheticals."

After his election, Youngkin's flexible stance on certain issues, like nuclear energy and eased plastic regulations, contrasts with his firm position on marijuana possession, which he wants to re-criminalize. His refusal to distance himself from conspiracy theorists in his party has drawn criticism. Youngkin campaigned for a controversial figure, Paul LePage, who made racist comments and apologized only according to Youngkin. Following the assault on Nancy Pelosi's husband, Youngkin used the opportunity to criticize the Pelosis, which was seen as inappropriate by Virginia Democrats. After initial reluctance, Youngkin apologized for his rhetoric in a letter to Nancy Pelosi. Youngkin's approval ratings among Virginians are not mentioned in the text.
